question.title: In Java, should I use `@Override` for record fields?
question.body:
If my record implements an interface, with a field accessor implicitly implementing a method, it should be an instance of what the @Override annotation is meant to cover.

interface I { int f(); }
record R(@Override int f) implements I {}

But seems javac doesn't not check it. Is it still a good idea to use it? Why javac ignores @Override on record fields?

answers.body:
There is no need for @Override for a record field, or better, for its getter method in that example.

A record class is implicitly final, it cannot be extended, so it cannot be abstract (actually a compile error if so declared), no abstract methods are allowed; that implies that all methods from the interface must be implemented. In other words, the compiler will signal an error even without the annotation.

it eventually serves as documentation

mlecz, record's don't have fields but instead components. These do allow @Override. The original code snippet compiles just fine.

The way I read it, the question is two-fold:

  1. Should we use @Override on record components? I've seen my IDE complain that @Override was missing in the past, but I just checked and I don't get a warning anymore.
  2. Why does javac ignore @Override on record components? javac doesn't enforce them, just like it doesn't enforce them on methods. However, it doesn't give a compiler error if a record component is annotated with @Override incorrectly, where it does for methods. My IDE also doesn't give any errors.

The JLS is clear on @Override for records, see section 9.6.4.4. It explicitly states that it's not a compiler error if a record component is annotated with @Override, whether it's correct or not. I also states that the only way to enforce the semantics of @Override is in fact exactly what mlecz suggests.
No need. As Rob said, you'll get a compiler error anyway if you don't implement all interface methods. There is no risk of failing to implement a method.

@Target(ElementType.METHOD)
@Retention(RetentionPolicy.SOURCE)
public @interface Override {
}

Override targets method, so it does not work on a field. Right now the only way to achive what you want is

interface I {
    int f();
}

record R(int f) implements I {
    @Override
    public int f() {
        return f;
    }
}
